finding: The SNP rs7210219 indicated mixed associations across disorders ASD and PTSD, reflecting complex genetic interfaces.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The lead variant rs28670687, associated with type 1 diabetes (T1D), exhibited a significant effect size (OR=1.42) with a low BFDR of 1.36%. It was noted that rs28670687 was in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with three 3' UTR variants, suggesting potential causality, although definitive separation from a larger credible set was not achieved.
title: Enhanced genetic analysis of type 1 diabetes by selecting variants on both effect size and significance, and by integration with autoimmune thyroid disease

finding: The rs58296998 SNP was identified as an intronic SNP and eQTL of the PRKCA gene. Each additional risk allele conferred 2.4 times the odds of symptomatic cryptosporidiosis in the first year of life, suggesting a significant association between this SNP and increased susceptibility to cryptosporidiosis.
title: Genome-wide association study of cryptosporidiosis in infants implicates PRKCA

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with T-helper cells LSES, indicating its relevance in immune response mechanisms.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP demonstrated significant associations with T-helper and CD8 T-cell responses within the immune signature landscape.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP was linked with significant associations in immune traits, particularly with T-helper and CD8 T-cells.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP had significant associations with multiple immune traits related to T-cell subsets.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: The SNP rs34579536 was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium with KANSL1 and was associated with a potential functional impact on KANSL1 protein function. It was previously linked to PD risk, contributing to the understanding of KANSL1's role in the disease.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The SNP rs35833914 was reported as being in high linkage disequilibrium with KANSL1. This SNP formed part of the allelic variations that were suggested to directly influence KANSL1 expression and thus its role in PD.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The SNP rs34043286 was noted for its high linkage disequilibrium with KANSL1 and its potential effect on PD risk through impacting KANSL1 protein functionality or expression.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: The SNP rs12185268 was identified as a tagging SNP in high linkage disequilibrium with both the H1 and H2 haplotypes, and its association with allele-specific expression in KANSL1 was demonstrated, suggesting the H1 allele had a protective impact relative to PD risk.
title: Regulation of mitophagy by the NSL complex underlies genetic risk for Parkinson’s disease at Chr16q11.2 and on the MAPT H1 allele

finding: Associated with the left middle frontal cortex, this variant exhibited a z-score of 7.11, marking it as significant within the regional connectivity analysis.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: Linked to the left middle frontal cortex, this SNP had a z-score of 6.66, indicating a strong relationship with regional connectivity.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This variant was linked to cardiovascular disease traits, contributing to the understanding of shared genetic risk factors.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The minor allele of the rs17689918 SNP in the <italic>CRHR1</italic> gene was linked to an increased risk for panic disorders specifically in women. This finding was significant as it highlighted how carriers of this allele exhibited greater fear generalization to safety cues, alongside increased activation of the amygdala and decreased activation in the frontal cortex during fear conditioning tasks. These results suggested that abnormal CRF signaling caused by this SNP could contribute to prolonged fear responses, even when environmental cues indicated safety.
title: Sex differences in fear regulation and reward seeking behaviors in a fear-safety-reward discrimination task

finding: Associated with heel bone mineral density, it showed the strongest expression effect for GAS72 in cultured fibroblasts.
title: Genome-Wide Large-Scale Multi-Trait Analysis Characterizes Global Patterns of Pleiotropy and Unique Trait-Specific Variants

finding: The missense variant rs17681684 in GLP2R was found associated with higher risks of type 2 diabetes and increased citrulline levels, indicating a locus-specific metabolic relationship.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: This SNP was identified in the CIMBA/BCAC-TN meta-analysis and showed opposite associations for luminal A-like and triple-negative (TN) breast cancer subtypes, with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.13 for luminal A-like and 0.67 for TN (P=7.0×10^-6 for ER and P=2.07×10^-4 for HER2). It also showed associations with high-grade serous cancers (OR=0.75) and low-grade serous cancers (OR=1.58), revealing its role as a susceptibility variant with subtype-specific effects.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies 32 novel breast cancer susceptibility loci from overall and subtype-specific analyses

finding: The SNP rs4566208 associated with Parkinson's disease demonstrated colocalisation with an i-eQTL regulating a novel exon of ZSWIM7, thus highlighting its relevance in PD risk.
title: Regulatory sites for known and novel splicing in human basal ganglia are enriched for disease-relevant information

finding: This SNP served as a lead signal at the HNF1B locus and was primarily assigned to islet tissue, with a maximum PPA of 0.72.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: This SNP was a lead signal assigned to liver at the HNF1B locus and was categorized as a potential causal variant with high PPAs for liver.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs1042522 was detected in hESCs and iPSCs prior to and following CEPT treatment. Its presence did not change during passaging (passages 0, 10, and 20), suggesting stability in this variant. The finding related to its characterization as likely benign according to ClinVar, indicating that CEPT treatment did not induce alterations in this SNP.
title: A Versatile Polypharmacology Platform Promotes Cytoprotection and Viability of Human Pluripotent and Differentiated Cells

finding: The SNP rs13342232 was identified as a T2D risk variant that contributed to decreased SLC16A11 expression and function in the liver. This disruption was shown to affect glucose metabolism in liver cells, leading to increased intracellular lactate and a shift towards triacylglycerol accumulation, related to type 2 diabetes conditions.
title: Mct11 deficiency alters hepatic glucose metabolism and energy homeostasis

finding: The SNP rs75493593 was also part of the identified T2D risk haplotype. It was found to promote similar effects on SLC16A11 expression, mirroring the changes attributed to rs13342232, consequently influencing liver metabolism and increasing the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
title: Mct11 deficiency alters hepatic glucose metabolism and energy homeostasis

finding: Identified as part of a best model at GRB2, rs12936583 was linked with joint effects across contact, accessibility, and expression, highlighting its significance as a trimodal QTL.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: As a candidate in a best model with moderate LD alongside rs12936583, this variant was chosen for its associations with multimodal genetic effects in GRB2.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: This SNP was associated with NCOR1 expression and overlapped with a known GWAS variant, indicating relevance to white blood cell count.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: In a study from 2016, it was found that the PER1 rs3027172 genotype interacted with early life stress to predict problematic alcohol use. This indicates that there was a clear association between this SNP and substance use behavior in relation to stress, which highlights its potential involvement in addiction pathways, particularly in behavioral aspects related to alcohol.
title: Circadian- and sex-dependent increases in intravenous cocaine self-administration in Npas2 mutant mice

finding: The SNP rs1042522, associated with the P72R mutation of TP53, correlated with elevated susceptibility to hemolysis following osmotic insults, implicating this variant in hemolytic risk.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The SNP rs1800371 (H178R mutation in TP53) was noted for associations with osmotic fragility in RBCs, underscoring its influence on hemolytic responses.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: This SNP, associated with the R248Q mutation in TP53, was linked to susceptibility to hemolysis after osmotic challenges, reiterating TP53's role in RBC hemolytic mechanisms.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: The TP53 SNP rs8064946 was significantly associated with markers of osmotic fragility and showed connections to various lipid peroxidation-related pathways, indicating its potential impact on RBC survivability.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: It was noted in studies associating breast cancer with genetic factors, further supporting its role in breast cancer susceptibility.
title: DOT: Gene-set analysis by combining decorrelated association statistics

finding: The SNP rs267606711, an extremely rare mutation in the CD79B gene, was associated with agammaglobulinemia 6, an immunodeficiency characterized by profoundly low or absent serum antibodies and low or absent circulating B cells. This finding supported the role of CD79B in blood cell indices, with strong associations noted in TWAS for lymphocyte count, hematocrit, plateletcrit, white blood cell count, and hemoglobin percentage.
title: Transcriptome-wide association study in UK Biobank Europeans identifies associations with blood cell traits

finding: The study demonstrated that rs1058808 in the ERBB2 gene, with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.33, was associated with a preferential amplification of the allele that produced a weaker MHC class I binding epitope. This provided evidence that higher binding affinity for the reference allele led tumors to selectively amplify the alternative allele, which was seen in heterozygous individuals showing this amplification.
title: Germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts breast cancer subtypes and metastatic proclivity

finding: The findings for rs1292053 in the TUBD1 gene, with a MAF of 0.45, were similarly significant. The data indicated that tumors tended to amplify the alternative allele preferentially when its MHC class I binding affinity was higher than that of the reference allele, resulting in a higher prevalence of the reference allele amplification in the analyzed population.
title: Germline-mediated immunoediting sculpts breast cancer subtypes and metastatic proclivity

finding: The SNP rs8080626 was associated with a GIS-based assessment of vulnerability to aeolian desertification in the Source Areas of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers as reported by Ren et al. in 2016. This finding highlighted the relationship between genetic markers and environmental factors, particularly in the context of soil quality and degradation.
title: Response of soil microbial communities to alpine meadow degradation severity levels in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau

finding: The SNP rs1801690 was associated with both cis eQTL and pQTL effects in the gene APOH, linked to creatine kinase levels. This connection was statistically significant and demonstrated potential relevance to cardiovascular traits.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: The SNP rs11658168 was recognized as a trans eQTL encoding for TNNT2, a cardiac structural protein, implying its influence on transcriptional regulation as related to AF.
title: Tissue-specific multiOMICs analysis of atrial fibrillation

finding: SNP rs4292 was significantly associated with ACE gene expression in kidney tubules, where higher T allele dosage led to increased ACE expression, highlighting its role as a PT cell-specific eQTL.
title: Mapping the genetic architecture of human traits to cell types in the kidney identifies mechanisms of disease and potential treatments

finding: The SNP rs8080306 was determined to be a likely causal variant that regulates the expression of the gene PRKAR1A. This SNP was found within a transcription factor binding site (TFBS) in the promoter region of PRKAR1A, and was also an eQTL, indicating its potential role in influencing PRKAR1A expression and, consequently, its association with Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathways.
title: Genome-wide prediction and integrative functional characterization of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genes

finding: The variant rs10512441, found 15 kb upstream of TMEM98, was associated with myopia in population studies. This SNP is located in a regulatory region of active chromatin, implying its potential role in the regulation of TMEM98 expression. Furthermore, TMEM98 mutations were implicated in causing dominant nanophthalmos, highlighting the relationship between this variant and eye size regulation.
title: The nanophthalmos protein TMEM98 inhibits MYRF self-cleavage and is required for eye size specification

finding: The SNP rs17649553 was associated with expression of 11 nearby genes in the DG-GCL, including 9 that were also significant in bulk hippocampus. The p-values for these associations were notably strong, with 8 genes at p < 1e-20. This SNP exemplified the distinct regulatory effects present in DG-GCL not observed in homogenate tissue.
title: Cell type-specific genetic regulation of expression in the granule cell layer of the human dentate gyrus

finding: The heterozygous expression of SNP rs56014026 was found to maintain quiescent metabolism and promote goblet cell differentiation in colorectal cancer (CRC) cells. It was specifically characterized to be expressed in low-grade colorectal carcinomas in patients. This finding was put into context with the dietary intervention that increased tumoral p32 expression, thereby highlighting a link between this SNP and the metabolic reprogramming of CRC towards balanced oxidative phosphorylation, which could prevent tumor progression.
title: Colorectal cancer progression is potently reduced by a glucose-free, high-protein diet: comparison to anti-EGFR therapy

finding: The locus rs17608766 was associated with several electrical physiology traits, including QRS duration and blood pressure. This association underscored its relevance in cardiac anatomy and gene expression variations within skeletal muscle, indicating its multifaceted impact on cardiac physiology.
title: Genomic analysis reveals a functional role for myocardial trabeculae in adults

finding: The well-characterized HOXB13 variant rs138213197 had a strong association with prostate cancer (P = 1.72e-7). It was linked to long-range linkage disequilibrium beyond 1Mb, indicating its evolutionary significance as a rare yet highly penetrant mutation.
title: Association Study of Over 200,000 Subjects Detects Novel Rare Variants, Functional Elements, and Polygenic Architecture of Prostate Cancer Susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs9906189, located at chr17:36549567 G/A, displayed strong associations with the overall promoter activity for both decomposed promoters of the gene GGNBP2. The frQTL beta values were 0.222 and -0.222 for decomposed promoters 1 and 2, respectively, indicating a switch in decomposed promoter usage. However, this switch resulted in a limited impact on overall promoter activity, as reflected by a prQTL beta of -0.063.
title: Promoter sequence and architecture determine expression variability and confer robustness to genetic variants

finding: The variant rs563260668, identified as SNV3, was noted for its potential polymorphic nature in a human population, occurring in approximately 1 out of 152,152 individuals according to gnomAD v4.0. Its presence in this database highlights its relative rarity and the fact that it does not match the predicted ancestral state, suggesting it is derived in Neanderthal. This finding contextually associates the variant with specific Neanderthal jaw features, indicating a possible link to morphological traits observed in Neanderthal populations.
title: Neanderthal-derived variants shape craniofacial enhancer activity at a human disease locus

finding: The RNF213 variant, R4810K (rs112735431), was established as significantly associated with Moyamoya disease (MMD) in a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in 2011. This variant was implicated in earlier onset and more severe deterioration of MMD. It was found to be more prevalent in adult patients, associated with a higher risk of cerebral hemorrhage, while the homozygotic variant was more commonly observed in children with MMD.
title: RNF213 variant and autophagic impairment: A pivotal link to endothelial dysfunction in Moyamoya disease

finding: This SNP was associated with CLM-6 protein levels, explaining 5.3% of the phenotypic variance in plasma protein levels with a significant p-value of 3.4 × 10^-10.
title: Genetic and epigenetic architectures of neurological protein biomarkers in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936

finding: The G-allele of rs7209826 was associated with 0.04 g/cm² higher estimated heel-bone BMD (eBMD), translating to a 41% lower risk of fracture (OR 0.59) and a 57% lower risk of osteoporosis (OR 0.43). Furthermore, this variant linked with higher BMD also indicated higher expression of sclerostin mRNA in tibial artery tissues, suggesting functional relevance.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: The A-allele of rs188810925 correlated with 0.07 g/cm² higher eBMD, resulting in a 41% lower fracture risk (OR 0.59) and a 57% lower risk of osteoporosis (OR 0.43). Similar to rs7209826, this SNP also associated with lower sclerostin mRNA expression in aorta tissues, tying it to sclerostin's regulatory effects.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: As a proxy for rs7209826, rs7220711 was utilized due to its high linkage disequilibrium (r²=0.99) and demonstrated a similar genetic association trend with BMD, allowing for relevant assessments in the analysis.
title: Lifelong genetically lowered sclerostin and risk of cardiovascular disease

finding: This SNP was in the CRLF3 gene and showed a P-imputed value of 5.12×10^-6, indicating it might be involved in the pathogenesis of cutaneous leishmaniasis.
title: A genome-wide association study highlights a regulatory role for IFNG-AS1 contributing to cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil

finding: The SNP rs62621376 on chromosome 17, located within the gene TTYH2, was associated with the occipital fusiform gyrus in terms of regional grey matter volume.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: Associated with FLCN isoforms and pulse rate, suggesting a previously uncharacterized link to cardiac traits, thus presenting a novel GWAS signal.
title: Fine mapping spatiotemporal mechanisms of genetic variants underlying cardiac traits and disease

finding: The G/G genotype of the rs8067378 SNP was found to upregulate GSDMB1 expression in both non-cancerous and cancerous cervical tissues. However, it increased the expression of the other three isoforms (GSDMB2-4) only in tumor tissues, indicating a differential effect of this SNP in various tissue contexts.
title: Distinct GSDMB protein isoforms and protease cleavage processes differentially control pyroptotic cell death and mitochondrial damage in cancer cells

finding: The rs11078928-C allele, associated with asthma risk, was reported to produce exon 6 skipping, which prevented the translation of a caspase-1 cleavage site at D236. This resulted in the production of a pyroptosis-deficient GSDMB-NT in bronchial epithelial cells, highlighting the SNP's impact on the function and processing of GSDMB.
title: Distinct GSDMB protein isoforms and protease cleavage processes differentially control pyroptotic cell death and mitochondrial damage in cancer cells

finding: The study established that the COL1A1 rs1800012 polymorphism was associated with musculoskeletal degenerative diseases. This association highlighted the relevance of variations in collagen genes such as COL1A1 in the context of connective tissue integrity and the phenotypes related to bone fragility and structural properties.
title: Collagen (I) homotrimer does not cause bone fragility but potentiates the osteogenesis imperfecta (oim) mutant allele

finding: This rare missense variant in the GLTPD2 gene was strongly associated with lower levels of sphingomyelin (SM(d40:0)), with a p-value of 1.1E-12, and suggestively associated with other SMs.
title: Leveraging a founder population to identify novel rare-population genetic determinants of lipidome

finding: The study confirmed that the region 48,416 bp downstream of the MAPT promoter, where the H1c tagging variant rs242557 is located, was crucial for MAPT expression. Targeting this region resulted in approximately 40% reduction in MAPT expression, with significant knockdown of MAP3K14 expression and an increase in NSF expression. Moreover, the alternate allele of rs242557 was previously associated with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD), suggesting the genetic variant's relevance in the context of neurodegeneration.
title: MAPT expression is mediated by long-range interactions with cis-regulatory elements

finding: The SNP rs145766379 was found to correlate significantly with the rearrangement at the SUZ12P1-CRLF3 locus and was implicated as a potential informant for the initial cause of rearrangement. It was associated with increased likelihood of secondary structure formation near observed breakpoints, suggesting a role in genomic instability potentially leading to neurofibromatosis type I.
title: Discovery of A Polymorphic Gene Fusion via Bottom-Up Chimeric RNA Prediction

finding: This SNP was identified at chromosome 17 and included the MAPT gene associated with Parkinson's disease. It showed a significant correlation with beat synchronization, indicating its potential role in neurodevelopment.
title: Genome-wide association study of musical beat synchronization demonstrates high polygenicity

finding: The variant rs61676547 was located in an intron of the BPTF gene and was found to overlap a fetal-specific ATAC-seq peak. It demonstrated significant allele-specific expression (ASE) with a p-value of 1.9 x 10^-7. This SNP is linked to type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk and is associated with HDL cholesterol, indicating that its functional effects may be restricted to the fetal pancreas and not observed in adult pancreatic tissues.
title: iPSC-derived pancreatic progenitors are an optimal model system to study T2D regulatory variants active during fetal development of the pancreas

finding: The SNP rs3169950 served as a significant cis-eQTL for the target gene PSMB6 in gliomasphere cells with a Bonferroni-adjusted p-value of 2.93 x 10^-12. The alternative A allele was associated with higher levels of PSMB6 expression. The SNP was located near the transcription start site of PSMB6 and was linked to increased binding affinity of transcription factor YY1, influencing the transcription process and regulatory mechanisms at this locus.
title: Discovering single-cell eQTLs from scRNA-seq data only

finding: The SNP rs9635700, located on chromosome 17, was noted to exhibit a more consistent MAF of 0.315-0.41 across three studies in dbSNP. The findings suggested that the minor allele signal detected from rs201947198 may actually relate to rs9635700, thereby causing the observed interchromosomal linkage between the two.
title: Allele Frequency Mismatches and Apparent Mismappings in UK Biobank SNP Data

finding: The SNP rs113994135, corresponding to the substitution R382W, was identified as pathogenic and deleterious by four different software tools, and its pathogenicity was consistent with findings in the literature.
title: In Silico Genetics: Identification of pathogenic nsSNPs in human STAT3 gene associated with Job’s syndrome

finding: The SNP rs113994139, corresponding to the substitution V637M, was also found to be pathogenic and supported by previous studies, indicating its deleterious effect on the STAT3 protein.
title: In Silico Genetics: Identification of pathogenic nsSNPs in human STAT3 gene associated with Job’s syndrome

finding: The SNP rs669915 showed significant association with expression levels, particularly influencing the expression of the pseudogene LRRC37A4P with exceptionally strong p-values (LIBD dataset minimum p=1.96 × 10^-99; CMC dataset p=3.99 × 10^-65). This was crucial in understanding mood instability (MI) as it highlights possible genetic underpinnings contributing to psychiatric disorders.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: The rs9909004 locus, associated with DCM through adverse left ventricular modeling, showed a suggestive association for the Q-R slope trait at P=3.5×10^-4, located in the PRKCA gene.
title: The genetic makeup of the electrocardiogram

finding: The rs5848 variant of the progranulin gene was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease, as reported in multiple studies including findings from Sheng et al. (2014) and Lee et al. (2011), which highlighted the relevance of this polymorphism in varying populations.
title: Granulins rescue inflammation, lysosome dysfunction, and neuropathology in a mouse model of progranulin deficiency

finding: The SNP rs2872507 was associated with reduced expression of the gene GSDMB, which was linked to multiple phenotypes including Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and rheumatoid arthritis, demonstrating shared genetic effects.
title: Mendelian Randomization integrating GWAS and eQTL data reveals genetic determinants of complex and clinical traits

finding: SNP rs144216645 was significantly associated with both left-handed versus non-left-handed (p=1.2E-09) and right-handed versus non-right-handed (p=2.3E-08) phenotypes, located within a large inversion haploblock on chromosome 17.
title: The molecular genetics of hand preference revisited

finding: The SNP rs766783183 within the KRT25 gene was originally identified during the genomic screening for Hypotrichosis 8. Initially, this variant was ranked at 172 when only human phenotypic information was used. However, upon incorporating mouse and fish phenotype data, the prioritisation ranking significantly improved to rank 8. This provided evidence that rs766783183 was ultimately confirmed as the molecular diagnosis for Hypotrichosis 8, highlighting the importance of utilizing model organism phenotype data in variant prioritisation.
title: Towards a standard benchmark for variant and gene prioritisation algorithms: PhEval - Phenotypic inference Evaluation framework

finding: The SNP rs1108591 was identified to overlap with specific peaks in EC4, being linked to the PECAM1 gene. This finding emphasized its potential association with endothelial cell mechanisms relevant to CAD.
title: Single cell ‘omic profiles of human aortic endothelial cells in vitro and human atherosclerotic lesions ex vivo reveals heterogeneity of endothelial subtype and response to activating perturbations

finding: The research referenced Dragozi et al. (2016), which explored the correlation between burn severity and GeoEye images, forming a basis for the methods applied in the analysis of forest fires and the resulting vegetation impacts in the Tanzania study.
title: Integrating geospatial tools in mapping forest fire severity and burned areas in the Western Usambara Mountain Forests, Lushoto, Tanzania

finding: The SNP rs62059712 was noted to link to multiple gene promoters across both beta and alpha cell types, with a PPAg of 0.34. This highlights the complexity of genetic interactions in islet cells related to type 2 diabetes, with the SNP implicated in various gene regulatory mechanisms.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs2012 was linked to the characteristics of the apicomplexan-like microalga Chromera, which was found to exhibit greater thermal tolerance compared to its Symbiodiniaceae counterparts. This finding was significant in understanding the potential of Chromera as a more resilient mutualist for corals under temperature stress.
title: Close relationship between coral-associated Chromera strains despite major differences within the Symbiodiniaceae

finding: The study by Dong et al. in 2011 indicated that the rs391300 G/A polymorphism in the serine racemase (SRR) gene influenced the therapeutic efficacy of metformin in Chinese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. This finding related to the context of diabetic retinopathy (DR), suggesting that variations at this locus could impact treatment outcomes for patients with diabetes.
title: Inhibition of serine racemase prevents diabetic retinopathy

finding: The analysis indicated that rs242557 was associated with increased MAPT expression and altered splicing in vitro, particularly within a regulatory region of MAPT intron 1. This variant was situated within a region enriched for active enhancer marks and was found to be significant in case-control analyses concerning Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) and associated with chromatin accessibility in glial cell types.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: This SNP served as a haplotype tagging SNP for the H1/H2 classification at the 17q21.31 locus. The association analysis established that rs8070723 was linked to an odds ratio (OR) of approximately 1.22 indicating an increased risk for Parkinson's Disease (PD) through the H1 haplotype.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Associated with PSP risk, rs242562 showed statistical significance in analyses, indicating an OR of 1.44. This SNP was also found to create a peak in chromatin accessibility specifically in microglia and neurons with H1c status, highlighting its functional involvement in gene regulation linked to neurodegenerative diseases.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Identified as being located within a weak enhancer region specific to the brain, rs8076152 did not exhibit an open chromatin peak. It was associated with PSP, but its specific contribution to the pathology was less clear compared to other SNPs.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Found to be part of the genetic signals across the MAPT and KANSL1 locus, rs35838379 was associated with PSP risk and played a role in the broader ascertainment of haplotype complexities at 17q21.31.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Distinguished by its independent effect in conditional analyses, rs6503455 was implicated as a significant contributor to haplotype signals that associate with PSP risk, indicating its potential role in neuropathology.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Provided insights in the association analysis, rs58810165 emerged with potential independent effects related to PSP, adding to the complexity of the 17q21.31 locus associations.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Exhibited a strong association with PD in a large case-control cohort, this SNP had an odds ratio of approximately 1.22 for the H1 haplotype, reinforced by both datasets supporting its relevance.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: Demonstrated an association with PD risk, particularly in the context of H1 homozygotes, where it presented as a top SNP with an OR of 1.21, albeit with decreased statistical significance in further analyses.
title: 17q21.31 sub-haplotypes underlying H1-associated risk for Parkinson’s disease and progressive supranuclear palsy converge on altered glial regulation

finding: The heterozygous P32/C1QBP/HABP1 polymorphism rs56014026 was previously identified as reducing mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and was expressed in low-grade colorectal carcinomas. This finding highlighted the potential impact of the SNP on mitochondrial function, relevant to the malignant progression as observed with PA28γ in the context of OSCC.
title: PA28γ promotes the malignant progression of tumor by elevating mitochondrial function via C1QBP

finding: As part of the genetic variants under study, rs35897051 contributed to the understanding of Alzheimer's disease by being identified with significant joint under-expression in RNA and proteins, thus showcasing its relevance to AD.
title: The functional impact of rare variation across the regulatory cascade

finding: Its regulation of the CCR7 gene was established, showing significant expression effects in conjunction with the EBP41 gene in specific blood cell types.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: Impacting the expression of CCR7, this SNP was highlighted for its contribution to lymphocyte dynamics.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: In the context of Li-Fraumeni syndrome, the rare germline variant rs78378222 located in the TP53 3' UTR was identified as a potential new mechanism of cancer predisposition. This highlighted an important relationship between the genetic alteration and the impairment of p53 function, which is essential for maintaining genome integrity and effective DNA damage response.
title: Oncogenic alterations in the p53 pathway abolish oscillatory competence

finding: Associated with amplitude traits, rs9899649 was located in the 17p11.2 genomic region and contributed to the genetic understanding of intrinsic brain activity.
title: Common variants contribute to intrinsic functional architecture of human brain

finding: It was prioritized by WEVar as a potential causal regulatory variant associated with platelet counts, scoring higher than three LD-linked GWAS SNPs.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: Associated with cleft lip/palate, it significantly decreased enhancer activity and was prioritized with the highest score in its risk locus.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs273534, found on Chromosome 17, represented a significant locus related to cognitive traits. It was notably associated with general cognitive ability and Reaction Time, with the largest association specifically with Reaction Time, suggesting that this SNP may primarily be linked to speeded cognitive abilities, rather than a broad association with genetic g.
title: Genetic “General Intelligence,” Objectively Determined and Measured

finding: This SNP was shown to loop to the promoters of multiple genes, including SP2, PRR15L, CDK5RAP3, NFE2L1, CBX1, and HOXB3, suggesting its involvement in the regulation of insomnia-related genes within a 700 kb region.
title: Variant-to-gene-mapping followed by cross-species genetic screening identifies GPI-anchor biosynthesis as novel regulator of sleep

finding: The SNP rs11867934 was identified as the most significant retinopathy-associated eSNP among a set of 7,253 tested eSNPs. An analysis showed a meta-GWAS P value of 6.7×10^-6 with an odds ratio of 0.86 (95% CI 0.71, 1.00), indicating its potential role in diabetic retinopathy. This intergenic eSNP for the gene folliculin (FLCN) exhibited differential expression in human lymphoblastoid cell lines, revealing that FLCN was more upregulated in response to glucose in individuals with diabetic retinopathy compared to those without it. The finding was reinforced by additional studies across three large, independent cohorts.
title: Mendelian randomization identifies folliculin expression as a mediator of diabetic retinopathy

finding: The risk allele showed significantly higher transcriptional activity relative to the normal allele in LNCaP cells, denoting a positive influence on gene expression.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: The SNP rs1052553 was identified as significant in both the original GWAS and the cFDR analysis. It showed a small p-value of 0.007 for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in the discovery GWAS and a smaller p-value of 1.649e-15 in the validation study, indicating a strong association with RA. Additionally, it overlapped a regulatory factor binding site.
title: fcfdr: an R package to leverage continuous and binary functional genomic data in GWAS

finding: The polymorphism rs7214723 in CAMKK1 was found to be associated with cardiovascular diseases, indicating a potential genetic risk factor for heart failure.
title: Identification of biomarkers, pathways and potential therapeutic targets for heart failure using bioinformatics analysis

finding: The minor allele of rs56201815, a synonymous variant in ERN1, was associated with significantly increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD) among APOE ε4 non-carriers. The analysis revealed that this SNP increased expression of ERN1 in important brain regions and was linked to lower average FDG uptake, suggesting its role in the pathology of AD.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs12373123 was identified as a significant eQTL for multiple genes including GRN and MAPT, showing a protective effect against AD. Its minor allele was associated with decreased AD risk in APOE ε4 non-carriers.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: Previously reported as having potential associations with AD but did not reach genome-wide significance in recent analyses.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs62057153, located within the CRHR1 gene, showed a strong association with SA-derived GIBNs, particularly associated with SA1, having a p-value ranging from 5.22×10−17 to 8.45×10−21. This SNP was implicated in a GWAS of schizophrenia.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The SNP rs9909861 was associated with SA6, with previous associations to subcortical volumes and cognitive abilities noted.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The variant rs1126642, associated with GFAP, was linked to significant brain regions, notably in white matter, and related to glial cell structure and functions pertinent to neurological disorders.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: The study by Montazeri-Najababady et al. (2021) established an association between the TP53 rs1625895 polymorphism and the increased risk of sarcopenic obesity in older Iranian adults, indicating a potential role of this SNP in metabolic disorders.
title: Bioinformatics Analysis of next generation sequencing data for Risk Prediction in Patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs7207400 was found to be associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) traits, highlighting its relevance in neurodegenerative conditions.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: Similarly, rs199499 was also linked with traits connected to Alzheimer's disease, confirming its association with neurodegenerative phenotypes.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs9303521 was associated with depressed affect, supporting its role in mental health disorders.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs7225384 showed an association with depressed affect, further contributing to the evidence that genetic variations in this region are relevant to mental health conditions.
title: The Genetic Heterogeneity of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: The SNP rs2331413 was highlighted as having significant associations with the ERN1 gene, which functions in the unfolded protein response pathway. This gene's role as a sensor of unfolded proteins links it to drug-induced hepatotoxicity, a phenotype previously associated with the ERN1 locus in genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Three downstream genes associated with rs2331413 were also identified as endoplasmic reticulum proteins, emphasizing the biological relevance of the finding.
title: DataRemix: a universal data transformation for optimal inference from gene expression datasets

finding: The SNP rs5848 was identified as being associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD), as detailed in the study by Sheng et al. in 2014. This finding highlighted the genetic link between the polymorphism in the Progranulin gene and susceptibility to AD, which aligns with the broader investigation into how genetic variations may influence neuroinflammatory responses in the context of AD.
title: Microglial amyloid beta clearance is driven by PIEZO1 channels

finding: The study identified the C/C genotype for rs5848 in the RedPenMC and C/T in AMC.26, highlighting that the 'C' allele represented a less efficient binding site for miR-659, which is known to inhibit GRN translation, thereby affecting the expression of GRN associated with frontotemporal dementia.
title: Single-cell multimodal omics and directly reprogrammed neurons to probe reduced penetrance in Frontotemporal Dementia

finding: Genotyping revealed the T>G substitution (c.882T>G) at g.42428777T>G for rs794729670 associated with the pathogenic GRN variant (p.Tyr294*) in carriers, which was further confirmed through family member analyses.
title: Single-cell multimodal omics and directly reprogrammed neurons to probe reduced penetrance in Frontotemporal Dementia

finding: The rs9890231 SNP located in ITGB4 was associated with Aβ40 in the TBS fraction and showed evidence of influencing the splicing of ITGB4.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs7210937 was noted for showing evidence of population differentiation with a high Fst value between African and European populations. It was part of a microRNA seed sequence that affected the targeting properties, suggesting that shifts in allele frequencies could impact novel target site frequencies.
title: Pervasive selection against microRNA target sites in human populations

finding: The SNP rs9889296 was located 75.9kb from the CCL8 gene and was implicated by fine mapping as an eQTL. This finding associated this SNP with the inflammatory skin disease phenotype, particularly highlighting its role within the T<sub>h</sub>17-dependent gene module.
title: T cells promote distinct transcriptional programs of cutaneous inflammatory disease in human skin structural cells

finding: The SNP rs78761021 was associated with type 2 diabetes risk, being linked to GLP2R where it showed a high LD (0.87) with the citrulline-associated variant rs17681684, supporting its relevance in metabolic disorders.
title: Cross-platform genetic discovery of small molecule products of metabolism and application to clinical outcomes

finding: The SNP rs2070935 was found to influence GFAP expression in relation to astrocytoma grade. This finding indicated that variations at this SNP could be linked to altered GFAP levels, particularly in the context of Pilocytic Astrocytomas (PA) and their characteristics, such as the presence of Rosenthal fibers. These associations reflected the distinction in astrocyte responses between different grades of gliomas.
title: Aquaporin-4 expression levels and mis-localization are inversely linked to peritumoral edema in gliomas of varying aggressiveness

finding: The rs242559 SNP was identified as the most significant SNP for POAG in this study. It was located within an intron of MAPT and showed significant associations with traits related to cognitive decline and neurological conditions.
title: A large cross-ancestry meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies identifies 69 novel risk loci for primary open-angle glaucoma and includes a genetic link with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This SNP is part of the MAPT haplotype, associated with increased risk of Parkinson's disease (PD), and included in the analysis of iPSC lines for common genetic risk factors.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: In a previous study related to blood lipid levels in the Dutch population, the rare variant rs77542162 was found to be associated with this phenotype, highlighting its relevance in genetic studies related to metabolic health.
title: NyuWa Genome Resource: Deep Whole Genome Sequencing Based Chinese Population Variation Profile and Reference Panel

finding: This SNP was associated with blood pressure (P = 2 x 10^-46) and QRS interval duration (P = 1 x 10^-44), found intronic to GOSR2 and looping to WNT9B.
title: Detailed Regulatory Interaction Map of the Human Heart Facilitates Gene Discovery for Cardiovascular Disease

finding: The SNP rs62088464 was identified within a GATA motif sequence in a GATA3 ADT-associated peak. The risk allele, which preserved the GATA motif, was associated with decreased pulmonary function as measured by decreased forced vital capacity, a characteristic that can occur in pulmonary fibrosis and inflammatory lung diseases associated with Th2 immune responses. In the analysis, it was found that the risk allele was more accessible in cells exhibiting high levels of GATA3 protein, suggesting that GATA3 binds to the risk sequence to activate the regulatory element for the target gene TSEN54, which is linked to type-2 airway inflammation.
title: NEAT-seq: Simultaneous profiling of intra-nuclear proteins, chromatin accessibility, and gene expression in single cells

finding: The IKZF3 gene rs12946510 was associated with the onset and severity of multiple sclerosis, which may reflect shared genetic susceptibility linked to metabolic and autoimmune diseases like T2DM.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: This SNP was confirmed as a positive finding for T2E prostate cancer with an OR of 1.52 and a p-value of 5.05 x 10^-3.
title: Germline determinants of the prostate tumor genome

finding: The rs2750012 polymorphism in GLOD4 was associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) in the Arab population of northern Israel. This association was further supported by a meta-analysis performed on seven independent GWAS datasets, confirming the relevance of GLOD4 to AD.
title: Association of GLOD4 with Alzheimer’s Disease in Humans and Mice

finding: The reQTL effect for SLFN5 was noted to have cell-type specific effects in the IAV perturbation experiment, demonstrating significant interaction effects across different immune cell types.
title: Modeling heterogeneity in single-cell perturbation states enhances detection of response eQTLs

finding: The SNP rs2269907 was identified as a variant that increased gene expression. It was localized in an active candidate enhancer region and was found within a ChIP-seq peak for the JunD transcription factor. The presence of this variant corrected a mismatch in the JunD motif, thereby facilitating JunD binding, which positively regulated gene expression.
title: Deciphering regulatory DNA sequences and noncoding genetic variants using neural network models of massively parallel reporter assays

finding: This SNP was known to significantly affect transcription factor (TF) binding and demonstrated a substantial impact on DNA breathing, affecting 11 base-pairs around the SNP region.
title: Examining DNA Breathing with pyDNA-EPBD

finding: The finding indicated that the rs150929926 SNP causes a Q130R mutation in NLRP1, which significantly eliminated the protein's susceptibility to cleavage by CVB3 3C<sup>pro</sup>. This reduction in cleavage susceptibility further led to a loss of NLRP1 inflammasome activation in response to identified viral proteases, highlighting the impact of this specific mutation on host immune response.
title: Diverse viral proteases activate the NLRP1 inflammasome

finding: The study provided evidence that the GG genotype of SNP rs12936231 in ZPBP2 was associated with a protective effect on asthma risk in children, while the CC or GC genotypes showed no response to vitamin D. The finding was linked to higher sphingolipid production.
title: Vitamin D constrains inflammation by modulating the expression of key genes on Chr17q12-21.1

finding: SNP rs4065275, adjacent to ORMDA3, was functionally relevant to asthma and was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs12936231, suggesting its role in modulating asthma risk through interactions affecting the transcription of ORMDL3.
title: Vitamin D constrains inflammation by modulating the expression of key genes on Chr17q12-21.1

finding: The rs1042522 SNP, located in the coding region of the TP53 gene, was identified as a high-risk mutation associated with multiple tumorigenesis. This mutation was confirmed to be present in HepG2 hepatoma cells but absent in normal liver HL7702 cells. Moreover, the mutation was found in the cervical cancer cell lines HeLa, SiHa, and C-33a, indicating its potential role in carcinogenesis related to both HPV infection and the TP53 mutation.
title: CRISPR-assisted targeted enrichment-sequencing (CATE-seq)

finding: The rs7212349 SNP, which was identified as the top associated variant for the gene SARM1, exhibited a significant association with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), with a P-value of 1.8e-7. Although this P-value did not meet the conventional genome-wide significance threshold, the study highlighted its relevance in AMD pathogenesis. The association reinforced the idea that integrating eQTL data with GWAS can enhance gene discovery for complex diseases.
title: Towards the identification of causal genes for age-related macular degeneration

finding: The SNP rs78378222, located at the TP53 locus, was associated with melanoma and lymphocytic leukemia, providing a significant link to the genetic basis of these cancers.
title: Pan-Cancer Study Detects Novel Genetic Risk Variants and Shared Genetic Basis in Two Large Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs4968783 was associated with a significantly increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease, with an odds ratio (OR) of 13.20 per 10mmHg lower systolic blood pressure (SBP), having a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 2.14 to 81.24 and a p-value of 0.005. This finding suggested a strong protective effect linked to antihypertensive medication targeting angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.
title: Repurposing antihypertensive drugs for the prevention of Alzheimer’s disease: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: The rs11867855 G allele in the SHMT1 gene was found to associate with increased appendicular lean mass, with a p-value of 2.9e-9 and a beta of 0.0132. Functional analysis showed that this variant affects gene expression significantly in testis (p<0.0000063), indicating its role in muscle mass maintenance.
title: Skeletal muscle hypertrophy rewires glucose metabolism: an experimental investigation and systematic review

finding: The SNV rs5918 was associated with susceptibility to Andes orthohantavirus (ANDV) infection in a Chilean population. The TT genotype, which codes for leucine at position 33 of the PSI-domain of the β3 integrin, was found in 89.2% of ANDV cases and in 60% of exposed close-household contacts who remained uninfected (p<0.05). Conversely, the protective CC genotype (coding proline) was completely absent in all 85 ANDV cases and present in only 11.4% of exposed close-household contacts who did not contract the virus. The presence of the TT genotype was linked to logistic regression models showing an odds ratio (OR) of 6.2-12.6 for becoming a case among individuals engaged in known risk activities, demonstrating a clear association with increased susceptibility to ANDV infection.
title: Single nucleotide variant at the αvβ3 integrin associated to Andes virus infection susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs2291725 was associated with an S>G amino acid exchange in the Gastric Inhibitory Polypeptide (GIP) and was connected to traits such as body fat, coronary artery disease, and diabetes. This novel finding related to GIP, a protein not previously reported in affinity proteomics GWAS, underscored its potential role in these clinical phenotypes.
title: Nanoparticle Enrichment Mass-Spectrometry Proteomics Identifies Protein Altering Variants for Precise pQTL Mapping

finding: The SNP rs563336550 was associated with a rare variant protein quantitative trait locus (RV-pQTL) related to the GRN gene (progranulin). It was noted for having a significant splice donor variant linked to a strong burden effect that identified its role in proteomic levels, despite the overall burden signal not replicating in the Pomak cohort.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: The rs5848 polymorphism was found to be associated with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Studies showed that individuals with this variant had reduced plasma and brain levels of granulin, indicating a link between PGRN levels and the pathophysiology of AD. Additionally, it was reported that PGRN deficiency in mice led to notable changes in plaque dynamics and microglial activation, marking the importance of rs5848 in the context of FTLD and AD.
title: A multifaceted role of progranulin in regulating amyloid-beta dynamics and responses

finding: The TP53 polymorphism rs1625895 was associated with the risk of sarcopenic obesity among older adults, indicating its role in obesity-related health outcomes.
title: Study on potential differentially expressed genes in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis by bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The rs25531 SNP, located in the 5-HTTLPR gene, was found to be associated with neuroticism through its influence on the resting state functional connectivity (RSFC) of the amygdala and fusiform gyrus. This connection highlighted implications for understanding the neurobiological underpinnings of personality traits related to major depressive disorder (MDD). The study by Kruschwitz et al. (2015) illustrated the significance of this SNP in the context of emotional and cognitive processes, linking genetic variants to specific brain functioning that may relate to MDD symptoms.
title: Contrastive Functional Connectivity Defines Neurophysiology-informed Symptom Dimensions in Major Depression

finding: The SNP KCNJ2-rs236514 was associated with diet quality and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in an elderly cohort. This finding suggested that variations in this SNP could influence dietary factors that are potentially linked to cognitive decline in older adults.
title: A Continuous Extension of Gene Set Enrichment Analysis using the Likelihood Ratio Test Statistics Identifies VEGF as a Candidate Pathway for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The study identified a natural variant K61E in the C-C motif chemokine 14 proteoform, which was directly associated with the SNP rs16971802 documented in the dbSNP database. The presence of K61E significantly influenced proteoform expression in different plasma donors. In a comparative analysis, the wild type (PFR 98045) was exclusively expressed in one donor (biorep01), while another donor (biorep03) exhibited no detectable wild type due to being homozygous for K61E. Notably, further genome sequencing was suggested to explore the implications of this single-site mutation on proteoform stability and overall gene expression.
title: Deep Profiling of Plasma Proteoforms with Engineered Nanoparticles for Top-down Proteomics

finding: rs79600142 was associated with total surface area (SA) and was linked to cognitive traits such as educational attainment and neuroticism. It was found in the chromosome 17q21.31 inversion region, which has also been associated with Parkinson’s disease.
title: The genetic architecture of the human cerebral cortex

finding: The SNP rs224534 was identified by the Coupled Mixed Model (CMM) method as being associated with both Alzheimer's disease (AD) and substance use disorder (SUD). It was located within the TRPV1 gene, which encodes the transient receptor potential cation channel subfamily V member 1. Previous studies indicated that positive modulation of TRPV1 channels could be a potential target for mitigating AD, highlighting the gene's role in the disease. Furthermore, evidence showed that TRPV1 is crucial in morphine addiction and plays a significant role in alcohol-related behaviors, establishing connections between TRPV1 and both substance use disorders and alcoholism.
title: Coupled Mixed Model for Joint Genetic Analysis of Complex Disorders with Two Independently Collected Data Sets

finding: The SNP rs1136287, associated with the mHA STSPTTNVL from the gene SERPINF1, was linked to an increased risk of disease-related mortality (DRM), with an HR of 2.32 and a 95% CI of [1.5, 3.6], and a P-value of 0.008 in individuals with HLA-C*03:04.
title: Associations of Minor Histocompatibility Antigens with Clinical Outcomes Following Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: The TP53 SNP rs1042522 showed an interaction with the use of NSAIDs, where GG homozygotes had a decreased risk of CRC when using NSAIDs compared to C-allele carriers, which replicated earlier findings that indicated protective benefits of NSAIDs for homozygotes.
title: Intake of red and processed meat, use of non-steroid anti inflammatory drugs, genetic variants and risk of colorectal cancer; a prospective study of the Danish “Diet, Cancer and Health” cohort

finding: The finding related to rs80357915, a deleterious germline BRCA1 mutation (c.4611_4612insG; p.Gln1538Alafs), showed that veliparib treatment in a patient with advanced triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) significantly enhanced the immune response. This was evidenced by a 25% increase in CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, a 75% increase in CD20+ B-lymphocytes, and a 33% reduction in CD4+ helper T cells after 6 weeks of treatment. Moreover, there was a noteworthy rise in PD-L1 expression in both tumor and immune cells, suggesting an immunomodulatory effect from veliparib treatment specifically in BRCA1 deficient tumors.
title: Chromatin-Bound PARP1 Correlates with Upregulation of Inflammatory Genes in Response to Long-Term Treatment with Veliparib

finding: The SNP rs535861886 was found in patient 103 and affected a binding site occupied by the EGR2 transcription factor. This finding was part of a broader analysis that highlighted the significance of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) in regulatory gene modules relevant to common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) patients.
title: Decoding mutational hotspots in human disease through the gene modules governing thymic regulatory T cells

finding: The SNP rs74639548 was identified in patient 113, influencing a binding site associated with the EGR2 transcription factor. This discovery contributed to understanding the accumulation of SNVs in TFBS among CVID patients.
title: Decoding mutational hotspots in human disease through the gene modules governing thymic regulatory T cells

finding: The SNP rs11080327 was identified as an expression SNP (eSNP) for the gene SLFN5, indicating a significant association between this SNP and the expression level of the SLFN5 gene. Additionally, it was classified as a causal SNP (cSNP) for a chromatin peak located within the first intron of SLFN5, suggesting that changes in this SNP could influence regulatory mechanisms affecting this gene.
title: The Trouble with Triples: Examining the Impact of Measurement Error in Mediation Analysis

finding: Common SNP rs5918 (PlA1/A2) in the ITGB3 gene was linked to an increased risk of coronary artery disease, which may intersect with cardiovascular risks in diabetic patients, including those with gestational diabetes.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and signaling pathways in gestational diabetes mellitus by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs6505162 C>A polymorphism in the miRNA-423 gene exhibited a protective association against the occurrence of coronary artery lesions (CAL) and coronary artery aneurysms (CAA) in Kawasaki disease (KD) patients. Specifically, CA/AA genotypes were found to reduce the risk of CAA (Adjusted OR=1.30, P=0.037) and CAL (Adjusted OR=1.56, P=0.001) in the studied population of southern Chinese KD patients. However, there was no significant association between this polymorphism and overall KD susceptibility.
title: The rs6505162 C>A polymorphism in the miRNA-423 gene exhibits a protective element of coronary artery in a southern Chinese population with Kawasaki disease

finding: The study identified that SNP rs6503650 in the JUP gene significantly associated with the methylation levels of all 14 hub CpG sites within the brown co-methylated module. This association indicated that JUP played a central role in regulating the methylation behavior of genes within this module, which was correlated with insulin levels, C-peptide levels, and body mass index (BMI). The findings suggested that JUP could influence glucose uptake and insulin sensitivity, highlighting its potential as a target for understanding T2DM risk factors.
title: Network analysis after epigenome wide methylation study revealed JUP as a regulator of co-methylated risk-module for T2DM

finding: The SNP rs12938775 was associated with the gene PAFAH1B1, which plays a role in neural mobility and activation of Rho GTPases like RHOA. Although PAFAH1B1 had a lower locus to gene score compared to the highest scoring gene CLUH, it demonstrated stronger brain-specific expression patterns and was also linked to unipolar depression.
title: An atlas of protein-protein associations of human tissues prioritizes candidate disease genes

finding: The C allele at rs12938658 was found to increase the expression of the FLOT2 gene in pre-menarcheal females, while its effect trended oppositely in post-menarcheal females. FLOT2 is implicated in asthma risk via a Transcriptome-Wide Association Study (TWAS).
title: Analysis of transcriptional changes in the immune system associated with pubertal development in a longitudinal cohort of children with asthma

finding: The rs538628 SNP was associated with left-handedness and demonstrated connections to mood swings, neuroticism, and educational attainment. It is located near genes with neurological functions, including NSF, which may play a role in GABAergic synapse pathways.
title: RSGenome-wide association study identifies 49 common genetic variants associated with handedness

finding: The study found that the patient harbored a p.P72R variant in the TP53 gene, which was confirmed as somatic in multiple tumor types. This variant, associated with the common SNP rs1042522, led to decreased inhibition of PGC-1α, a regulator of mitochondrial functions, potentially enhancing tumor cell migration and invasion. The analysis indicated that all reads from 53 cells contained this variant, suggesting homozygosity, despite previous reports of heterozygosity in GBM cases showing a preference for the p.P72R allele in tumor tissue.
title: Scalable co-sequencing of RNA and DNA from individual nuclei

finding: The rs4968366 SNP was recognized as the lead stress-interactive eQTL for the HSF5 eGene in the dACC, where its effects on gene expression were modified by stress levels.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: The SNP rs62063655 was noted as the lead stress-interactive eQTL for the STX8 gene in the BLA, indicating that its relationship with gene expression was influenced by levels of stress.
title: Common genetic variation impacts stress response in the brain

finding: The SNP rs4790904 was associated with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in a U.S. Caucasian and African-American veteran sample. This association underscored the genetic risk factors influencing PTSD, contributing to the understanding of genetic heritability in this condition. The findings highlighted the significance of specific variants like rs4790904 in the context of PTSD pathways.
title: Analysis of Genetically Regulated Gene Expression identifies a trauma type specific PTSD gene, SNRNP35

finding: The study confirmed a mutation in the TP53 gene, specifically TP53:c.395A>T, p.Lys132Met (rs1057519996), which was consistent with Li-Fraumeni Syndrome. This mutation led to the somatic inactivation of the wild-type TP53 allele through deletion in the tumor samples analyzed.
title: Long-read sequencing of diagnosis and post-therapy medulloblastoma reveals complex rearrangement patterns and epigenetic signatures

finding: A strong selection signal at MAPT (rs4792897), coding for tau protein related to neurodegenerative disorders, was noted with a significant association to Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs12946510 in the IKZF3 gene was identified as associated with multiple sclerosis onset and severity, highlighting its involvement in the genetic predisposition to MS.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs2107538 in the CCL5 gene was shown to be associated with multiple sclerosis risk factors, indicating a possible link to the immunological aspects of the disease.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs3760396 in the CCL2 gene was associated with the risk of multiple sclerosis, suggesting that genetic variants in chemokine signaling may influence disease susceptibility.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The variant rs56340929 located in the ARHGAP44 gene was identified as significantly associated with changes in HbA1c (ΔHbA1c) among non-diabetic subjects, explaining approximately 27% of the linkage peak on locus 17p12. This finding was reinforced by RNA expression data and replication studies.
title: A Novel Gene ARHGAP44 for Longitudinal Changes in Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) in Subjects without Type 2 Diabetes: Evidence from the Long Life Family Study (LLFS) and the Framingham Offspring Study (FOS)

finding: The C allele at rs921649 (C>T) increased susceptibility to autoimmune diseases, including type 1 diabetes (T1D), whereas it was associated with protection from asthma. This indicated a complex role of genetic risk factors influencing different diseases.
title: Specific type 1 diabetes risk genes underpin age-at-diagnosis and indicate joint defects in immunity, beta-cell fragility and responses to viral infections in early-onset disease

finding: The SNP rs35203463 was implicated as a cis-pQTL for granulin (GRN) that, when silenced, resulted in decreased platelet counts. This suggests a novel pathway linking GRN to CVD via its effects on platelet production.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: SNP rs850733 was also classified as a cis-pQTL for GRN and similarly showed that silencing GRN led to lower platelet counts, indicating its potential causal role in regulating platelet levels and linking it to cardiovascular disease.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: rs112735431 was identified as a lead variant causing a nonsynonymous substitution in the RNF213 gene. This variant displayed a strong association with coronary artery disease (CAD) development (OR CAD = 1.61, P = 2.3 x 10−21) and was also recognized as a susceptibility variant for moyamoya disease, particularly pertinent to the East Asian population.
title: Population-specific and transethnic genome-wide analyses reveal distinct and shared genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs112401631 was identified as a fine-mapped variant for asthma, with a posterior inclusion probability (PIP) of 0.27. It was linked to the gene CCR7 in various T cell subtypes such as CD8 effector, CD4 memory, CD8 naive, and CD4 naive, suggesting its significant role in T cell homing to lymphoid organs and its association with asthma severity.
title: Single-cell multiome regression models identify functional and disease-associated enhancers and enable chromatin potential analysis

finding: Variant rs2941506 was linked to a complete loss of GATA4 binding, yielding no detectable DNA binding, indicating a decrease in transcriptional activity. This SNP was associated with reduced expression of multiple genes including PGAP3 in cardiac tissue.
title: Cardiovascular Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Disrupt GATA4-DNA Binding and Regulatory Functions

finding: The SNP rs9896202 was fine-mapped to the gene CBX8, showing a strong cis-eQTL effect. This variant disrupted EGR1 transcription factor binding sites, indicating a potential role in gene regulation and contributing to understanding of eQTL mechanisms in diverse tissues.
title: The GTEx Consortium atlas of genetic regulatory effects across human tissues

finding: The study identified that the ITGB3 polymorphism at codon 33 of exon 2 (T1565C, rs5918) was significantly associated with altered platelet function. This polymorphism, specifically the PlA2 allele, correlated with increased platelet reactivity and has been implicated in aspirin resistance, suggesting its role as a critical genetic factor affecting the therapeutic efficacy of aspirin in cardiovascular patients.
title: CYP2C19*2, CYP2C19*17 and ITGB3 (PlA1/A2) polymorphisms and resulting therapeutic alterations of clopidogrel and aspirin: A clinical screening among CVD patients who undergone PCI

finding: The SNP rs1493550 was found to have a clear connection with the expression of the gene SLC39A11 (Solute Carrier Family 39 Member 11) and the methylation site cg26124719, which is located in an intron. This connection was resolved after correcting for residual effects of other features in multilevel models in the analysis performed using the KiMONo method. The results indicated that the SNP played a significant role in identifying expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) and expression quantitative trait methylation (eQTM), highlighting its relevance in the regulatory networks of the studied omic levels.
title: Knowledge guided multi-level network inference

finding: The SNP rs8080074 was associated with colorectal cancers, showing a significant relation to Wnt signaling pathways. This finding related to the malignancies influenced by canonical Wnt signaling, suggesting that alterations at this locus might affect the roles of ligands and receptors that are vital for proper cell differentiation and organ development.
title: Canonical Wnt signaling promotes formation of somatic permeability barrier for proper germ cell differentiation

finding: Associated with increased risks for colorectal cancer, this SNP also showed significant associations with anthropometric measurements, highlighting its potential phenotypic implications.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: Also observed to have similar associations as other Neandertal aSNPs, linked to complex phenotypes related to immune response.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The SNP rs3138036 was identified as a significant cis pQTL for MCP2, accounting for 35.80% of inter-individual variation in protein levels. This finding was consistent across Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) and Bayesian regression analyses.
title: Integrative omics approach to identify the molecular architecture of inflammatory protein levels in healthy older adults

finding: The rs4065275 variant was identified as the lead eQTL for ORMDL3, linked to rheumatoid arthritis, and exhibited significant interactions across various cell states, with the strongest effects observed in cytotoxic CD8+ T cells.
title: Modeling memory T cell states at single-cell resolution identifies in vivo state-dependence of eQTLs influencing disease

finding: The S209F variant of ABI3 (rs616338:p.Ser209Phe) was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease, with an odds ratio of 1.43 and a p-value of 4.5 × 10^-10. This finding indicated that this SNP was significantly correlated with Alzheimer's disease-related phenotypes.
title: ABI3 deletion in TgCRND8 mice is associated with reduced amyloid plaque pathology and altered glial response

finding: The rs5848 variant was found to influence GRN mRNA levels in both brain and peripheral mononuclear cells in patients with Alzheimer's Disease, thus highlighting its significance in neurodegenerative disease mechanisms. Additionally, this variant was associated with reduced plasma and brain levels of granulin, further indicating its role in Alzheimer's Disease pathology. A meta-analysis confirmed the association of the rs5848 polymorphism with neurodegenerative diseases, reinforcing its importance as a genetic risk factor.
title: Investigating the Role and Regulation of GPNMB in Progranulin-deficient Macrophages

finding: The SNP rs4792909 on 17q21.31 was associated with osteoporosis (P<sub>GWAS</sub> = 1.5E-74) and linked to gene <italic>G6PC3</italic> (P<sub>TWAS</sub> = 4.2E-26), suggesting a pathway influence on the disease.
title: Integrating genome-wide association and transcriptome predicted model identify novel target genes with osteoporosis

finding: The rs5848 SNP was identified as a risk factor for frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and Alzheimer's disease. In silico analyses indicated that this SNP affects the binding affinity of miR-659 to the GRN mRNA, leading to stronger binding and greater translational repression with the T allele. Individuals with the TT genotype (minor allele) exhibited approximately 30% decreased levels of progranulin protein in both brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), underscoring the role of miR-mediated modulation of progranulin levels in contributing to the risk of these dementias.
title: Antisense oligonucleotides targeting the miR-29b binding site in the GRN mRNA increase progranulin translation

finding: A variant within the SLC16A11 gene (rs117767867) was associated with an increased risk of diabetes. The allele frequencies based on local ancestry analysis in the Admixed American genetic ancestry group showed significant divergence when compared to the aggregate estimates, indicating that important disease-risk variants can be more accurately identified using LAI.
title: Improved Allele Frequencies in gnomAD through Local Ancestry Inference

finding: This variant was previously associated with height and demonstrated significant allelic bias in both differentiated and palmitate-stimulated cells, with notable enhancer activity for the alternate allele (G) compared to the reference allele (T). It showed nearly significant allelic differences in AICAR-stimulated conditions, highlighting its context-specific regulatory function in T2D-related metabolic processes.
title: Functional dissection of metabolic trait-associated gene regulation in steady state and stimulated human skeletal muscle cells

finding: The findings showed that rs62053943 had clear eQTLs in the MAPT region, likely corresponding to the H1/H2 haplotype status. This variant was associated with gene expression differences in the context of dopaminergic neurons.
title: The Foundational data initiative for Parkinson’s disease (FOUNDIN-PD): enabling efficient translation from genetic maps to mechanism

finding: The variant rs201961848 (p.A204S) associated with FG and FI was one of the rare missense variants found in the G6PC gene, highlighting its role in influencing glycemic traits.
title: Tissue-Specific Alteration of Metabolic Pathways Influences Glycemic Regulation

finding: The rs1801175 (p.R83C) variant in G6PC was noted for its association with fasting insulin (FI) and fasting glucose (FG) levels, in line with its function as a gluconeogenic enzyme.
title: Tissue-Specific Alteration of Metabolic Pathways Influences Glycemic Regulation
